Authors:
Mario Daniel Vargas-Luna, Patricia Hernández-Ledesma, Lucas
Charles Majure, Raúl Puente-Martínez, Héctor Manuel Hernández, Rolando
Tenoch Bárcenas-Luna
Title:
Splitting Echinocactus: morphological and molecular evidence
support the recognition of Homalocephala as a distinct genus in the
Cacteae
Keywords:
Cactaceae, Cactoideae, morphological character evolution,
North American Deserts.
Abstract:
Molecular phylogenetic studies of the six currently
accepted species in the genus Echinocactus have partially clarified
certain aspects of its phylogeny. Most of these studies lack a complete
sampling of Echinocactus and are based only in one source of data.
Phylogenetic uncertainties in Echinocactus, such as the recognition of
Homalocephala as a subgenus or as different to Echinocactus, the
exclusion or inclusion of E. grusonii or the affinities of E.
polycephalus, for example, still unresolved. The phylogenetic
relationships of Echinocactus were reconstructed with a maximum
parsimony, a maximum likelihood and a Bayesian approach including 42
morphological characters and four chloroplast markers (the atpB-rbcL,
trnH-psbA, trnL-trnF, and matK). The utility of two nuclear regions
related to the betalain cycles (DODA and 5GT) are explored and discussed
in relation to their potential as phylogenetic markers. The concatenated
analyses with the morphological and the molecular data sets, plus 13
indels (2847 characters and 26 taxa), show general agreement with
previous independent phylogenetic proposals. These results recovered a
polyphyletic Echinocactus, as E. grusonii was nested as sister to the
Ferocactus clade, reinforcing the already proposed exclusion of this
taxon. Furthermore, we recovered the rest of the species of Echinocactus
in two morphologically and molecularly well-supported clades, the
Homalocephala clade including E. texensis, E. parryi, and E.
polycephalus, and the Echinocactus clade including E. platyacanthus and
E. horizonthalonius, which was recovered as sister to the Astrophytum
clade. Consequently, we propose here to recognize the Echinocactus and
Homalocephala clades as two distinct genera. The evolution of some
morphological characters supporting these clades are discussed. The
necessary new taxonomic combinations for the Homalocephala clade and
identification keys for genera and species are presented.
